items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Update and /or Discussion regarding the First Year Implementation of New Tech at James Lick High School
	 
	 
Last school year, the staff at James Lick High School investigated the New Tech Network and went through a school-wide change process to determine if the school would adopt the New Tech model in order better prepare every student for the demands of our global society, better compete in the open market as a public high school, and establish the institutional changes that are required to meet the demands of the Common Core State Standards.
	 
The New Tech Network provides an established, comprehensive, instructional approach that includes interdisciplinary team teaching, project-based learning with technology embedded in the teaching and learning.  Students monitor their progress and skill building and develop a personal plan for college and career success.  The New Tech Network provides a comprehensive, embedded, four-year professional development program, which includes training, coaching and collaboration around project-based learning, as well as access to their vast network and library of resources.
	 
The school has completed its first semester of implementation at the 9th grade.  The district wants to recognize James Lick staff for their dedication and hard work in the transformation of teaching and learning.
items.item_text: Presentation, Update and /or Discussion regarding the First Year Implementation of New Tech at James Lick High School - Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
items.item_text_raw: 8.02 Presentation, Update and /or Discussion regarding the First Year Implementation of New Tech at James Lick High School - Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Student Representatives, James Lick High School, & Kelly Daugherty, Principal, James Lick High School
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation regarding Fitness Facility Remodel Proposal for James Lick High School:  A New Tech School
	 
	 
Obesity is a public health crisis.  Research indicates that one out of four high school students in Santa Clara County are overweight or obese.  As part of a class project, the James Lick High School New Tech freshmen students will be presenting to the Board of Trustees their assessment and proposal for a fitness facility remodel.    
	 
The students will present their proposed solution, types of equipment, and proposed cost.
items.item_text: Presentation regarding Fitness Facility Remodel Proposal for James Lick High School: A New Tech School - Student Representatives, James Lick High School, & Kelly Daugherty, Principal, James Lick High School

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Julie Kasberger, Director of General Services/Transportation, and Phil McConnell, School Bus Consultants
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Review and Accept the Fleet Management Study 
	 
On June 19, 2014, the Board awarded a contract to School Bus Consultants, SBC, to conduct a fleet management study (Board Item 18.01).  SBC collected financial, operational and programmatic data to analyze several areas of the District's fleet.  A site visit was conducted to gain first-hand observations on the operation and to review and collect additional data.  Department staff were interviewed to collect specific information on routing, vehicle maintenance, processes and procedures followed for fleet management.  The Fleet Management Study is attached.  
	 
SBC Project Manager, Phil McConnell, will present their process, findings and recommendations to the Board of Trustees.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
As stipulated by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: As stipulated by the Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
Members of the public may address the Board on any subject not on tonight’s agenda; however, provisions of the Brown Act (Government Code Section 54954.2(a) and 54954.3) preclude any action.  As an unagendized item, no response is required from the Board or District staff and no action can be taken; however, the Board may instruct the Superintendent to agendize the item for a future meeting.
	 
Any person may address the Board on any item on the meeting agenda.  Persons wishing to address the Board must fill out a gold request form, which is located at the entrance of the Board Room. When your name is called, please come to the podium, state your name for the record, and limit your remarks to three (3) minutes.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, and Rich Uribe, Director of Adult Education and Career Technical Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-15 recognizing the Month of February 2015 as Career Technical Education Month
	 
	 
Career Technical Education (CTE) brings together students, educators and employers to develop and strengthen the relationship between what's being taught in the classroom and its application in the workplace.  Its programs prepare students with 21st century skills. 
	 
CTE is made up of 15 industry sectors, which includes 58 career pathways related to all occupations.
A series of courses grouped together integrate academic and technical training to provide students with a pathway to postsecondary education and careers.
Some CTE classes stand alone, and others are found in California Partnership Academies, Multiple Pathway programs or Regional Occupational Programs.
CTE engages students, increases attendance and graduation rates, helps close the achievement gap, and raises grades. 
	 
East Side Union High School District honors Career Technical Education Month and collaborates with local industry, community organizations, and schools, including Alternative Education, ensures that students receive a 21st century education.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board adopt Resolution #2014/2015-15 recognizing the month of February 2015 as Career Technical Education month.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board adopt Resolution #2014/2015-15 recognizing the month of February 2015 as Career Technical Education month.

Item:  12.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Lawful Business Travel Expenses of Hoang Dinh, Certificated Teacher at Andrew Hill High School, to Vietnam
	 
	 
Board Policy 3350 requires Board approval for travel out of the country.  Approval by the Board is requested for Hoang Dinh's, certificated teacher at Andrew Hill High School, lawful business travel expenses as presented:
	 
Workshop on Teaching Vietnamese Language and Literature
Sponsored by:  International Association of Teaching Vietnamese
District covered travel dates:  March 27-30, 2015 
Location:  Vietnam
	 
The purpose of the travel is for Hoang Dinh to fulfill the International Baccalaureate (IB) Program recertification that is required every five years in order to continue teaching the IB Vietnamese class.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Authorized Lawful Business Travel Expenses
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Title II(a) Professional Development Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board approve the lawful business travel expenses of Hoang Dinh to Vietnam, March 27-30, 2015, for the purpose of attending a workshop on teaching Vietnamese language and literature.

meeting_sections.section_name: HUMAN RESOURCES - OPERATIONAL ITEMS/BOARD DISCUSSION AND/OR ACTION

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance, and Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager, Robert Ball, Bond Program Manager, SGI, and Greg Armendariz, Construction Manager, Swinerton Management & Consulting
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Update on Swimming Pool Modernization Project, and Request for Budget Augmentation
	 
	 
The districtwide Swimming Pool Modernization Project seeks to improve the swimming pool complexes at James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, William C. Overfelt, and Yerba Buena High Schools.  On December 11, 2012, the Board augmented the project budget in the amount of $10.5 million using Measure I funds (Item 16.03).  The Board of Trustees, pursuant to Education Code §17250.20, adopted Resolution 2012/2013-26 on March 21, 2013, to approve use of the design-build delivery method for the Swimming Pool Modernizations project affecting the remaining seven school sites (Item 15.03). 
	 
Through a prequalification process, the District selected two Design Build Entities (teams comprised of the firms that would provide comprehensive design and construction services).  A first round Request for Proposals was issued.  Proposals from each of the prequalified Design Build Entities were deemed nonresponsive.  The original construction management firm’s contract expired, and a new construction management firm was awarded a contract to complete the project. A second round Request for Proposals was issued; two responsive proposals were received and evaluated.
	 
Evaluation results indicate that some, but not all, the pools at the seven school sites can be modernized within the existing project budget.  This result was not unanticipated:  construction costs have been escalating due to workforce availability constraints associated with major public and private works in the region. In addition, the required scope of work has increased as new information about deteriorated and/or non code compliant existing conditions has become known through site investigations associated with design builder and construction management site visits during the proposal period.  
	 
With various levels of budget augmentation, additional options are available as delineated on the attached presentation.  
Option A shows what can be done within the existing budget of $12.5 million.  This option is not recommended, because it only provides a 30 year solution to four of the seven sites.
Option B is not recommended.  Although it provides a 30 year solution to all seven sites, fulfills aquatic program requirements for swim classes, competition swim, water polo and diving, it also has the highest initial and life cycle costs.
Options C and D are the most favorable options, fulfilling aquatic program requirements and having lower life cycle costs.  Option C satisfies 3 of 4 aquatic program options, but does not allow for diving.  Option D fulfills all the aquatic program requirements, at a slightly higher initial cost associated with provision of a deep corner for diving, and a slightly higher life cycle cost due to the increased volume of water that must be heated and treated, as well as increased energy consumption associated with larger pumping, filtration and heating equipment.
	 
The next step in the proposal process includes soliciting a “best and final” proposal from the design builder whose submitted proposal offered the best value (scored the highest points against stated evaluation criteria), so that administration can bring forth a recommendation of contract award in the coming months.  In order to do so, we must circle back to site administration and staff to finalize pool configurations (i.e., diving or not) and identify the deteriorated and/or suspected conditions that should be included in the contract.
	 
In order to achieve a satisfactory project outcome that will stand the test of time, make best use of available yet limited funds, provide equity of aquatic program opportunity to East Side students (not only among East Side’s schools, but also schools in adjacent districts against whom East Side students compete), and achieve the lowest life cycle cost against future general funds, administration recommends the Board of Trustees augment the project budget in an amount not to exceed $7.2 million – which would allow administration to pursue either Option C or D.  
	 
The majority of funding for this augmentation would be residual Bond Measure G interest revenue, which remains unallocated.  As of June 30, 2014, $5,131,188 of interest income is available; administration recommends the Board allocate all residual interest income – including interest earned after June 30 - to partially fund the swimming pool project budget augmentation.  The remainder of funding needed would not exceed $2,068,812, and would come out of Board discretionary Measure E proceeds.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not to exceed $7.2 million
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G residual interest revenue ($5,131,188)
Measure E Board discretionary funds (not to exceed $2,068,812)
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees augment the Swimming Pool Modernization project budget in an amount not to exceed $7.2 million, funded by Measure G residual interest revenue ($5,131,188 plus amounts earned subsequent to June 30, 2014), and Measure E Board discretionary funds not exceeding $2,068,812.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees augment the Swimming Pool Modernization project budget in an amount not to exceed $7.2 million, funded by Measure G residual interest revenue ($5,131,188 plus amounts earned subsequent to June 30, 2014), and Measure E Board discretionary funds not exceeding $2,068,812.

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Award of Bids and Request for Proposals for Bond/Capital Projects
		 
The attached award of bids and request for proposals for bond/capital projects is presented for review and approval as indicated in the attachment.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
See attachment
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
See attachment
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the award of bids and request for proposals for bond/capital projects as indicated in the attachment presented.
